content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the length \(l_0\)
Record \(l_0\) in Table 1.1 at load \(L = 0.0 \text{N}\)
Explain why \(l_0\) is **not** measured to point X on the spring
A student hangs a 1.0 N load on the spring. He records the new length \(l\) of the spring
He repeats the procedure using loads of 2.0 N, 3.0 N, 4.0 N and 5.0 N. The readings are shown in Table 1.1
Describe **one** precaution that you would take in order to obtain reliable readings
Plot a graph of \(l / \text{mm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(L / \text{N}\) (\(x\)-axis)
A student suggests that the length \(l\) of the spring is directly proportional to the load \(L\)
State whether your readings support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the graph line
Use the results to predict the load \(L\) that would give a length \(l\) twice the value of \(l_0\)
Show clearly how you obtained your answer
The class is investigating the stretching of a spring
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus

• On Fig. 2.1, draw a normal at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label this line \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{E}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{M}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\)
• Draw a line above \(\mathbf{AB}\) to the left of the normal and at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal. Label this line \(\mathbf{FE}\)
• Label the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) placed a suitable distance apart on \(\mathbf{FE}\) for accurate ray tracing

The student observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other. He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) are marked on Fig. 2.1
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal. Label this point \(\mathbf{K}\)
Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the line \(\mathbf{KM}\)
\(\alpha =\)
• Measure and record the length \(x\) between points \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{K}\)
The student repeats the procedure with the angle of incidence \(i = 50^{\circ}\)
His readings for \(\alpha\) and \(x\) are shown
A student suggests that the angle \(\alpha\) should always be equal to the angle of incidence \(i\)
State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the values of \(\alpha\) for \(i = 30^{\circ}\) and \(i = 50^{\circ}\)
statement
justification
Suggest one precaution that you would take with this experiment to obtain reliable results
The class is investigating the refraction of light passing through a transparent block. A student is using optics pins to trace the paths of rays of light
Fig. 2.1 shows the student's ray-trace sheet
The thermometer in Fig. 3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment
Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) during the first 180 s
\(\Delta \theta_{1} =\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) during the next 180 s
Suggest why \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) is different from \(\Delta \theta_{2}\)
A student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
• She measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the beaker
• She immediately starts a stopclock
• After 180 s, she measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water
• After 360 s, she measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water again
The readings are shown in Table 3.1
Another student plans to investigate the factors affecting the difference between the values of \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) and \(\Delta \theta_{2}\)
Suggest **two** changes that he could make to the procedure to obtain a larger value of this difference
The volume of water used in this experiment is measured using a measuring cylinder. Fig. 3.3 shows a measuring cylinder
A B, C and D are four possible lines of sight that could be used to read the volume of the water
Give **two** reasons why **B** should be used to obtain the most accurate reading
The class is investigating the cooling of water
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus
On Fig. 4.1, show clearly the length \(l\) of the pendulum
Use Fig. 4.2 to explain how you would measure the length \(l\) accurately. You may draw on the diagram
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum
Explain how measuring the time for 20 oscillations rather than one oscillation helps the student to obtain a more reliable value for the period
A student determines the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time taken for one complete oscillation. The student measures the time \(t\) for 20 oscillations
Fig. 4.3 shows the time \(t\)

parts.label: (c)

content.text: The student wants to determine a value for the acceleration of free fall from his results. He needs the value of \(T^2\) to do this
Calculate \(T^2\)
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures and include the unit

issues: LaTeX superscript (^) found outside math mode
LaTeX superscript (^) found outside math mode

content.text: The class is investigating the motion of a pendulum
Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus
A student is investigating whether the resistance of a wire depends on the material from which the wire is made
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
The following apparatus is available to the student:
ammeter
voltmeter
micrometer screw gauge
power supply (0–3 V)
variable resistor
switch
connecting leads
wires of different materials
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the resistance of a wire depends on the material from which it is made
You should:
* draw a diagram of the circuit you would use to determine the resistance of each wire
* explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take
* state the key variables that you would control
* draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
